The '''trials, tribunals, judicial committees and judicial hearings''' that followed the [[2011 Egyptian revolution]].
The '''trials, tribunals, judicial committees and judicial hearings''' that followed the [[2011 Egyptian revolution]].
â
Following the ouster of Mubarak, a series of arrests and/travel bans was imposed on high profile figures on charges of causing the death of 300-500 demonstrators, causing the injury of 5000 demonstrators, as well as charges of [[embezzlement]], [[profiteering]], [[money laundry]] and [[Human rights abuses|abuse of human rights]]. Among these figures are Mubarak himself, his wife [[Suzanne Mubarak]], his sons [[Gamal Mubarak|Gamal]] and [[Alaa Mubarak|Alaa]], former Interior Minister [[Habib el-Adly]], former Housing Minister [[Ahmed El-Maghrabi]], former Tourism Minister [[Zoheir Garana]] and the former secretary of the National Democratic Party for Organisational Affairs [[Ahmed Ezz]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2011/1036/eg31.htm |title=Al-Ahram Weekly | Egypt | How the mighty have fallen |publisher=Weekly.ahram.org.eg |date=2011-02-02 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> Additionally arrest warrants were issued against some public figures who left the country with the eruption of the revolution, on charges of financial misappropriations. Among these public figures are [[Rachid Mohamed Rachid]], the former mminster of trade and industry and Hussein Salem, a business Tycoon. Salem is believed to have left for Dubai<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globes.co.il/serveen/globes/docview.asp?did=1000619367&fid=1725 |title=Hussein Salem caught in Dubai with $500m |publisher=Globes |date=2011-01-31 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> Mubarak's ousted was also followed by widespread allegations of corruption against numerous other government officials and senior politicians,<ref>{{cite news|author=Phillip Inman |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/04/hosni-mubarak-family-fortune |title=Mubarak family fortune could reach $70bn, say experts | World news | guardian.co.uk |publisher=Guardian |date= 2011-02-04|accessdate=2011-03-23 |location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Ø¸â¦Ø·Â­Ø¸â¦Ø¸ËØ·Â¯ Ø¸â¦Ø·Â³Ø¸âØ¸â¦ |url=http://www.almasry-alyoum.com/article2.aspx?ArticleID=289811&IssueID=2068 |title=Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ¸â¦Ø·ÂµØ·Â±Ø¸â° Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ¸Ù¹Ø¸ËØ¸â¦ | Ø¸â¦Ø·ÂµØ·Â·Ø¸Ù¾Ø¸â° Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ¸Ù¾Ø¸âØ¸â°: Ø·Â´Ø·Â®Ø·ÂµØ¸Ù¹Ø·Â© Ø¸ÆØ·Â¨Ø¸Ù¹Ø·Â±Ø·Â© Ø¸Ù¾Ø¸â° Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â±Ø·Â¦Ø·Â§Ø·Â³Ø·Â© Ø·Â£Ø¸ÆØ·Â¯Ø·Ú¾ Ø¸âØ¸â° Ø·Â£Ø¸â  Ø¢Â«Ø¸â¦Ø·Â¨Ø·Â§Ø·Â±Ø¸ÆØ¢Â» Ø¸âØ¸â  Ø¸Ù¹Ø·Ú¾Ø·Â±Ø·Â´Ø·Â­ Ø¸ËØ·Â§Ø·Â¨Ø¸â Ø¸â¡ Ø·Â³Ø¸Ù¹Ø¸ÆØ¸ËØ¸â  Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â¨Ø·Â¯Ø¸Ù¹Ø¸â |publisher=Almasry-alyoum.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> including the former speaker of the Egyptian Parliament, [[Fathi Sorour]], and the former speaker of the higher legislative body ([[Shura Council]]), [[Safwat El Sherif]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/6644/Egypt/Politics-/NDP-fires-Mubarak--then-what.aspx |title=NDP fires Mubarak - then what? - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date=2011-02-28 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.masrawy.com/news/Egypt/Politics/2011/March/6/elshrief_announcement.aspx |title=Ø§ÙØ´Ø±ÙÙ ÙÙÙÙ Ø§ÙØªÙØ§ÙÙ Ø­Ø³Ø§Ø¨Ø§Øª Ø®Ø§ØµØ© Ø®Ø§Ø±Ø¬ ÙØµØ± |publisher=Masrawy.com |date=2011-03-06 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>

===Allegations of human rights abuses===
===Allegations of human rights abuses===
â
On March 5, 2011 and March 6, 2011 numerous Egyptian State Security buildings were stormed by demonstrators after reports that officials were witnessed shredding and burning documents that could serve as evidence against government officials.<ref name="dostor.org">{{cite web|url=http://dostor.org/politics/egypt/11/march/5/37549 |title=Ø¨Ø§ÙÙÙØ¯ÙÙ ÙØ§ÙØµÙØ±..Ø£ÙÙ Ø§ÙØ¯ÙÙØ© Ø¨ÙØ¯ÙÙØ© ÙØµØ± Ø¨Ø¹Ø¯ Ø§ÙØªØ­Ø§ÙÙ ÙØ§ÙØªØ­ÙØ¸ Ø¹ÙÙ ÙØ§ ØªØ¨ÙÙ ÙÙ ÙØ³ØªÙØ¯Ø§Øª Ø¯Ø§Ø®ÙÙ | Ø§ÙØ¯Ø³ØªÙØ± |publisher=Dostor.org |date=2011-03-05 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> Fires were simultaneously witnessed in a number of Egyptian State Security offices including Cairo downtown office (Lazoghly), 6 October city office, Damanhour, Nasr City, Marsa Matrouh and Alexandria.<ref name="ahram.org.eg">{{cite web|url=http://www.ahram.org.eg/464/2011/03/07/25/66174.aspx |title=Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â£Ø¸ËØ¸âØ¸â° - Ø¸ÆØ·Â´Ø¸â¬Ø¸Ù¾ Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ¸â¦Ø·Â³Ø·Ú¾Ø¸ËØ·Â± Ø¸Ù¾Ø¸â¬Ø¸â¬Ø¸Ù¹ Ø·Â£Ø¸â¦Ø¸â¬Ø¸â¬Ø¸â¬Ø¸â¬Ø¸â¬Ø¸â  Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â¯Ø¸ËØ¸âØ¸â¬Ø¸â¬Ø¸â¬Ø·Â© |publisher=Ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> Large amounts of shredded and burnt documents were found in different state security buildings.<ref name="almasry-alyoum.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.almasry-alyoum.com/article2.aspx?ArticleID=289708 |title=Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ¸â¦Ø·ÂµØ·Â±Ø¸â° Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ¸Ù¹Ø¸ËØ¸â¦ | Ø¸â¦Ø¸âØ·Â§Ø·Â± Ø¢Â«Ø·Â£Ø¸â¦Ø¸â  Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â¯Ø¸ËØ¸âØ·Â©Ø¢Â» Ø¸Ù¾Ø¸â° Ø¸â¦Ø·Â±Ø¸â¦Ø¸â° Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ¸â Ø¸Ù¹Ø·Â±Ø·Â§Ø¸â  |publisher=Almasry-alyoum.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> The demonstrators reportedly found evidence to support the widely accepted allegation of human rights abuses by Egyptian State Security. The independent newspaper [[Al-Ahram]] reported that Damanhour office of the Egyptian State Security was perhaps the most panic provoking, as prison cells with electrocution equipment were found in close proximity to a secret graveyard.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ahram.org.eg/464/2011/03/07/25/66081.aspx |title=Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â£Ø¸ËØ¸âØ¸â° - Ø·Â³Ø¸âØ¸ËØ·Â· Ø·Â¯Ø¸ËØ¸âØ·Â© Ø·Â£Ø¸â¦Ø¸â  Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â¯Ø¸ËØ¸âØ·Â© Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â¬Ø¸Ù¹Ø·Â´ Ø¸Ù¹Ø·Ú¾Ø·Â³Ø¸âØ¸â¦ Ø¸â¦Ø¸âØ·Â§Ø·Â± Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â¬Ø¸â¡Ø·Â§Ø·Â² Ø¸ËØ¸â¦Ø¸âØ·Â¨Ø·Â±Ø·Â© Ø·Â³Ø·Â±Ø¸Ù¹Ø·Â© Ø·Â¨Ø·Â¯Ø¸â¦Ø¸â Ø¸â¡Ø¸ËØ·Â± Ø¸ËØ·ØØ·Â±Ø¸Ù¾Ø·Â© Ø¸âØ¸âØ·Ú¾Ø·Â¹Ø·Â°Ø¸Ù¹Ø·Â¨ Ø·Â¨Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ¸ÆØ¸â¡Ø·Â±Ø·Â¨Ø·Â§Ø·Ø |publisher=Ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>

==Cases pertaining to public events==
==Cases pertaining to public events==
===Public disorder===
===Public disorder===
â
Numerous incidents of public disorder occurred from early days of the Egyptian uprising. On January 28, 2011 the police force withdrew from the street of Egypt. A number of prisons were broken into and prisoners were allowed to leave. Some prisons were allegedly opened by prison guards. On February 2, 2011, in what was latterly called the "Battle of the Camel" thugs stormed [[Tahrir square]] in downtown Cairo, where the demonstrators were stationed, and attacked them with Molotov cocktail, rocks, chipped marble, swords and other weapons from horse, donkey and camel backs. This battle resulted in the death of 91 demonstrators and the injury of several hundreds.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web|url=http://www.ahram.org.eg/The-First/News/67082.aspx |title=Ø·Â­Ø¸ËØ·Â§Ø·Â¯Ø·Â« - Ø¸â Ø¸âØ¸â Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â¬Ø·Â§Ø·Â¨Ø·Â±Ø¸Ù¹ Ø¸Ù¾Ø¸Ù¹ Ø·Â­Ø·Â±Ø·Â§Ø·Â³Ø·Â© Ø¸â¦Ø·Â´Ø·Â¯Ø·Â¯Ø·Â© Ø¸âØ¸âØ·Ú¾Ø·Â­Ø¸âØ¸Ù¹Ø¸â Ø¸â¦Ø·Â¹Ø¸â¡ |publisher=Ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> A national fact-finding panel was formed to investigate the cause of these incidents of public disorder. This panel was headed by Adel Koura, a judge.<ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite web|author=Ø¸â¦Ø·Â­Ø¸â¦Ø·Â¯ Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â³Ø¸Ù¹Ø·Â¯ Ø·ÂµØ·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â­ |url=http://www.almasry-alyoum.com/article2.aspx?ArticleID=289996 |title=Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ¸â¦Ø·ÂµØ·Â±Ø¸â° Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ¸Ù¹Ø¸ËØ¸â¦ | Ø¢Â«Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ¸â¦Ø·ÂµØ·Â±Ø¸â° Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ¸Ù¹Ø¸ËØ¸â¦Ø¢Â» Ø·Ú¾Ø·Â­Ø·ÂµØ¸â Ø·Â¹Ø¸âØ¸â° Ø¸â¦Ø·Â¹Ø¸âØ¸ËØ¸â¦Ø·Â§Ø·Ú¾ Ø¸â¦Ø¸â¡Ø¸â¦Ø·Â© Ø¸â¦Ø¸â  Ø·Ú¾Ø¸âØ·Â±Ø¸Ù¹Ø·Â± Ø¸âØ·Â¬Ø¸â Ø·Â© Ø¢Â«Ø·Ú¾Ø¸âØ·ÂµØ¸â° Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â­Ø¸âØ·Â§Ø·Â¦Ø¸âØ¢Â» Ø·Â­Ø¸ËØ¸â Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â§Ø¸â Ø¸Ù¾Ø¸âØ·Â§Ø·Ú¾ Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â£Ø¸â¦Ø¸â Ø¸â° |publisher=Almasry-alyoum.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>
+
Numerous incidents of public disorder occurred from early days of the Egyptian uprising. On January 28, 2011 the police force withdrew from the street of Egypt. A number of prisons were broken into and prisoners were allowed to leave. Some prisons were allegedly opened by prison guards. On February 2, 2011, in what was latterly called the "Battle of the Camel" thugs stormed [[Tahrir square]] in downtown Cairo, where the demonstrators were stationed, and attacked them with Molotov cocktail, rocks, chipped marble, swords and other weapons from horse, donkey and camel backs. This battle resulted in the death of 91 demonstrators and the injury of several hundreds.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite web|url=http://www.ahram.org.eg/The-First/News/67082.aspx |title=Abdul Nasser Al Jabri transfered under heavy guard for interrogation |publisher=Ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> A national fact-finding panel was formed to investigate the cause of these incidents of public disorder. This panel was headed by Adel Koura, a judge.<ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite web|author=Mohammed El-Sayyid Saleh |url=http://www.almasry-alyoum.com/article2.aspx?ArticleID=289996 |title=Â«Almasry AlyoumÂ» get important information from the report of the "fact-finding" Committee about the lawlessness |publisher=Almasry-alyoum.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>
The demonstrations of January 28, 2011, and the following days were met by acts of violence. The prosecution reported that upon examining the sites where the demonstrators were shot at empty bullets were found on rooftops of buildings surrounding [[Tahrir Square]], where the demonstrators were stationed. These buildings include the [[American University of Cairo]]. The University was closed at that time, and it is thought that armed officers and thuds had stormer these buildings and shot at the demonstrators. A similar scenario was reported in the area surrounding the Ministry of Interior in [[Cairo]], where demonstrators were shot at from the roof of this ministry. On March 10, 2011, [[Ismail El-Shaer]], the former security chief of Cairo was interviewed by prosecution regarding these incidents.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dostor.org/crime/11/march/10/37850 |title=Ø¥Ø³ÙØ§Ø¹ÙÙ Ø§ÙØ´Ø§Ø¹Ø± ÙÙØ«Ù ÙÙØªØ­ÙÙÙ Ø£ÙØ§Ù Ø£ÙÙ Ø§ÙØ¯ÙÙØ© Ø§ÙØ¹ÙÙØ§ ÙÙ Ø§ØªÙØ§ÙØ§Øª ÙØªÙ Ø§ÙÙØªØ¸Ø§ÙØ±ÙÙ | Ø§ÙØ¯Ø³ØªÙØ± |publisher=Dostor.org |date=2011-03-10 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> This was followed by the arrest of Adly Fayed, former Egyptian deputy interior minster for security, Hassan Abdulrahman, chief of state security, Ahmed Ramzy, chief of central security. All four were placed on remand for 15 days starting March 11, 2011.
The demonstrations of January 28, 2011, and the following days were met by acts of violence. The prosecution reported that upon examining the sites where the demonstrators were shot at empty bullets were found on rooftops of buildings surrounding [[Tahrir Square]], where the demonstrators were stationed. These buildings include the [[American University of Cairo]]. The University was closed at that time, and it is thought that armed officers and thuds had stormer these buildings and shot at the demonstrators. A similar scenario was reported in the area surrounding the Ministry of Interior in [[Cairo]], where demonstrators were shot at from the roof of this ministry. On March 10, 2011, [[Ismail El-Shaer]], the former security chief of Cairo was interviewed by prosecution regarding these incidents.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dostor.org/crime/11/march/10/37850 |title=Ø¥Ø³ÙØ§Ø¹ÙÙ Ø§ÙØ´Ø§Ø¹Ø± ÙÙØ«Ù ÙÙØªØ­ÙÙÙ Ø£ÙØ§Ù Ø£ÙÙ Ø§ÙØ¯ÙÙØ© Ø§ÙØ¹ÙÙØ§ ÙÙ Ø§ØªÙØ§ÙØ§Øª ÙØªÙ Ø§ÙÙØªØ¸Ø§ÙØ±ÙÙ | Ø§ÙØ¯Ø³ØªÙØ± |publisher=Dostor.org |date=2011-03-10 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> This was followed by the arrest of Adly Fayed, former Egyptian deputy interior minster for security, Hassan Abdulrahman, chief of state security, Ahmed Ramzy, chief of central security. All four were placed on remand for 15 days starting March 11, 2011.
â
Interrogation in this case started on March 12, 2011. [[Al-Ahram|Alahram]] daily newspaper reported that a CD recording of telephone conversations between [[Habib el-Adly]], the former interior minster of Egypt and Ahmed Ramzy, chief of central security, was examined as an evidence. In these conversations, Alahram reported, Ramzy received orders from el-Adly to use live ammunitions. Ramzy denied ordering the use of live ammunitions, but admitted that he ordered the use of rubber bullets and tear gas. Ramzy also stated that el-Adly ordered the withdrawal of the whole police force from the streets the evening of January 28, 2008 only after the military assumed responsibility. Ramzy claimed that this decision was made to avoid further confrontation between the police and the public. This account was supported by the statements of Adly Fayed, former Egyptian deputy interior minster for security, who confirmed that the withdrawal of the police force was to avoid further bloodshed.<ref name="ReferenceC">{{cite web|url=http://www.ahram.org.eg/The-First/News/66964.aspx |title=Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â£Ø¸ËØ¸âØ¸â° - Ø·Â­Ø·Â¨Ø·Â³ Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â§Ø·Â±Ø·Â¨Ø·Â¹Ø·Â© Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ¸ÆØ·Â¨Ø·Â§Ø·Â± Ø·Â¨Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â¯Ø·Â§Ø·Â®Ø¸âØ¸Ù¹Ø·Â© |publisher=Ahram.org.eg |date=2010-09-07 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>
+
Interrogation in this case started on March 12, 2011. [[Al-Ahram|Alahram]] daily newspaper reported that a CD recording of telephone conversations between [[Habib el-Adly]], the former interior minster of Egypt and Ahmed Ramzy, chief of central security, was examined as an evidence. In these conversations, Alahram reported, Ramzy received orders from el-Adly to use live ammunitions. Ramzy denied ordering the use of live ammunitions, but admitted that he ordered the use of rubber bullets and tear gas. Ramzy also stated that el-Adly ordered the withdrawal of the whole police force from the streets the evening of January 28, 2008 only after the military assumed responsibility. Ramzy claimed that this decision was made to avoid further confrontation between the police and the public. This account was supported by the statements of Adly Fayed, former Egyptian deputy interior minster for security, who confirmed that the withdrawal of the police force was to avoid further bloodshed.<ref name="ReferenceC">{{cite web|url=http://www.ahram.org.eg/The-First/News/66964.aspx |title=Imprisonment of four major heads of the Interior |publisher=Ahram.org.eg |date=2010-09-07 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>
[[Ismail El-Shaer]], the former security chief of Cairo, was also investigated for allegations of ordering the use of weapons against demonstrators and for causing public disorder, which he denied. He was also accused of being the driver in the widely publicized [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NrVI0pCysuU van incident], in which a police van was witnessed plowing into the demonstrators. El-Shaer denied that and stated that he was in his office at the time of this incident.<ref name="ReferenceC"/>
[[Ismail El-Shaer]], the former security chief of Cairo, was also investigated for allegations of ordering the use of weapons against demonstrators and for causing public disorder, which he denied. He was also accused of being the driver in the widely publicized [http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NrVI0pCysuU van incident], in which a police van was witnessed plowing into the demonstrators. El-Shaer denied that and stated that he was in his office at the time of this incident.<ref name="ReferenceC"/>
â

The events of February 2, 2011 (see above) also led to allegations that members of the [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party]] coordinated the activities of thugs who stormed [[Tahrir square]] on animal backs and attacked the demonstrators with rocks, swords and Molotov cocktail. The investigations of the fact-finding panel led by Adel Koura confirmed that two MPs from the National Democratic Party were involved in these events, allegedly coordinating the thugs activities and funding them. These two MPs were named in Al-Ahram newspaper: [[Youssef Khatab]] and [[Abdulnasser el-Gabri]], both were arrested on March 10, 2011.<ref name="ReferenceA"/>

The trial of Habib el-Adly follows two streams of legal charges: the first pertains to profiteering activities, and the second pertains to allegations that el-Adly ordered the use of live ammunitions against the demonstrators during January 2011 protests in different Egyptian cities, and was responsible for the opening of different jails in Egypt during these protests in order to cause criminal unrest and justify the use of force during these protests.<ref name="ahram1">{{cite web|url=http://www.ahram.org.eg/463/2011/03/06/25/65906.aspx |title=Al-Adli's Trial postponed to 2nd April and Al-Adli deny charges of profiteering and money laundering from inside the cage |publisher=Ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref> A fact finding panel was formed to assess the responsibility for incidents of criminal unrest. On March 9, 2011 the Egyptian daily newspaper Almasry Alyoum reported that el-Adly's charges in this case may be of political rather than criminal nature as there is an evidence available to the fact finding mission that he might have acted on orders from the countries president rather than at his own accord.<ref name="ReferenceB"/>
El-Adly appeared before Gize Criminal Court on March 5, 2011 where he was formally charged with profiteering and money laundry. These charges relate to allegations that el-Adly received a bribe of 4.5 million Egyptian pounds to allow a contractor to carry out some building work on behalf of the Egyptian ministry of interior. El-Adly pleaded not guilty, and the court proceedings were adjourned to April 2, 2011 to allow el-Adly's council to review the evidence. This trial was described by the Egyptian daily, [[Al-Ahram|Alahram]], as the Egyptian trial of the century.<ref name="ahram1"/> El-Adly's police department was widely feared by the Egyptians, and the allegations that he caused the widespread thuggery during and after the Egyptian protests of January 25/2011 to February 12/2011, by opening jails, led to large demonstrations infornt of the Giza Courthouse calling for el-Adly's execution.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/69C7960A-D11A-4E24-B1DF-E9E155609F0E.htm?GoogleStatID=20 |title=Ø§ÙØ£Ø®Ø¨Ø§Ø± - Ø¹Ø±Ø¨Ù - Ø§ÙØ¹Ø§Ø¯ÙÙ ÙÙØ«Ù Ø£ÙØ§Ù Ø§ÙÙØ¶Ø§Ø¡ Ø§ÙÙØµØ±Ù |publisher=Aljazeera.net |date=2011-03-05 |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>
El-Adly appeared before Gize Criminal Court on March 5, 2011 where he was formally charged with profiteering and money laundry. These charges relate to allegations that el-Adly received a bribe of 4.5 million Egyptian pounds to allow a contractor to carry out some building work on behalf of the Egyptian ministry of interior. El-Adly pleaded not guilty, and the court proceedings were adjourned to April 2, 2011 to allow el-Adly's council to review the evidence. On March 21, 2011, Alwafd daily newspaper reported that the possibility of a legal deal between the prosecution and some of those accused of embezzlement was explored. Alwafd stated that this option was explored after prosecution was successful in striking a deal with some creditors and business burrowers to repay a total of 13 billion Egyptian pounds in return for dropping legal charges. The situation with those listed above, according to Alwafd, proved more complex as the offers made by the accused, in return for dropping the embezzlement charges, were seen as unrealistic.<ref>http://www.alwafd.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=25966:Ø§ÙÙØ²Ø±Ø§Ø¡-Ø¹Ø±Ø¶ÙØ§-Ø±Ø¯-ÙØ§ÙÙØ¨ÙÙ-ÙØ§ÙÙÙØ§Ø¨Ø©-Ø±ÙØ¶Øª&catid=98:ÙØ­ÙÙØ©&Itemid=92</ref>
On March 21, 2011, Alwafd daily newspaper reported that the possibility of a legal deal between the prosecution and some of those accused of embezzlement was explored. Alwafd stated that this option was explored after prosecution was successful in striking a deal with some creditors and business burrowers to repay a total of 13 billion Egyptian pounds in return for dropping legal charges. The situation with those listed above, according to Alwafd, proved more complex as the offers made by the accused, in return for dropping the embezzlement charges, were seen as unrealistic.<ref>http://www.alwafd.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=25966:Ø§ÙÙØ²Ø±Ø§Ø¡-Ø¹Ø±Ø¶ÙØ§-Ø±Ø¯-ÙØ§ÙÙØ¨ÙÙ-ÙØ§ÙÙÙØ§Ø¨Ø©-Ø±ÙØ¶Øª&catid=98:ÙØ­ÙÙØ©&Itemid=92</ref>

===Public opinion ===

Concerns were raised that the accused will not be treated fairly due to the overwhelming public opinion against them. In an interview with Shabab Alahram newspaper, the known Egyptian lawyer Mohamed Hamoouda stated that his decision to withdraw from [[Hosni Mubarak|Hosni Mubarak's]] council was triggered by his belief that justice will not be achieved in these cases (see above under Mubarak's case). === Allegations of concealment and disposal of evidentiary documents===
=== Allegations of concealment and disposal of evidentiary documents===
â
On March 5, 2011 and March 6, 2011 numerous Egyptian State Security buildings were stormed by demonstrators after reports that officials were witnessed shredding and burning documents that could serve as evidence against government officials.<ref name="dostor.org"/> Fires were simultaneously witnessed in a number of Egyptian State Security offices including Cairo downtown office (Lazoghly), 6 October city office, Damanhour, Nasr City, Marsa Matrouh and Alexandria.<ref name="ahram.org.eg"/> These fires were witnessed the day after the government of [[Ahmed Shafik]], that last of Mubarak's prime ministers, had resigned. Large amounts of shredded and burnt documents were found in different state security buildings.<ref name="almasry-alyoum.com"/> The demonstrators reportedly found some documenta CDs, video and audiotape recordings pertaining to a number of recent events in Egypt including the explosion in the Two Saints Church in Alexandria on December 31, 2010, in which the state security apparatus, under [[Habib el-Adli|Habib El-Adli]], was allegedly involved. Documents pertaining to spying, blackmailing and torture activities were also found and handed over to the state prosecutor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ahram.org.eg/463/2011/03/06/38/65967.aspx |title=Ø·Â­Ø¸ËØ·Â§Ø·Â¯Ø·Â« - Ø·Â­Ø¸â¬Ø·Â±Ø·Â§Ø·Â¦Ø¸â Ø·Â¯Ø·Â§Ø·Â®Ø¸â¬Ø¸â Ø¸â¦Ø¸âØ¸â¬Ø·Â§Ø·Â± Ø·Â£Ø¸â¦Ø¸â¬Ø¸â  Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â¯Ø¸ËØ¸âØ¸â¬Ø¸â¬Ø·Â©Ã¢â¬Ú!Ã¢â¬Ú Ø¸â¡Ø·Â¬Ø¸ËØ¸â¦ Ø¸â¦Ø·Ú¾Ø·Â²Ø·Â§Ø¸â¦Ø¸â  Ø·Â¹Ø¸âØ¸â° Ø¸â¦Ø¸âØ·Â§Ø·Â± Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â¬Ø¸â¡Ø·Â§Ø·Â² Ø·Â§Ø¸âØ¸â¦Ø·Â±Ø·Â¹Ø·Â¨ Ø¸ËØ·Â¥Ø·Â­Ø·Â±Ø·Â§Ø¸â Ø¸âØ¸âØ¸ËØ·Â«Ø·Â§Ø·Â¦Ø¸â Ø¸ËØ·Â§Ø¸âØ·Â£Ø¸ËØ·Â±Ø·Â§Ø¸â |publisher=Ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>
+
On March 5, 2011 and March 6, 2011 numerous Egyptian State Security buildings were stormed by demonstrators after reports that officials were witnessed shredding and burning documents that could serve as evidence against government officials.<ref name="dostor.org"/> Fires were simultaneously witnessed in a number of Egyptian State Security offices including Cairo downtown office (Lazoghly), 6 October city office, Damanhour, Nasr City, Marsa Matrouh and Alexandria.<ref name="ahram.org.eg"/> These fires were witnessed the day after the government of [[Ahmed Shafik]], that last of Mubarak's prime ministers, had resigned. Large amounts of shredded and burnt documents were found in different state security buildings.<ref name="almasry-alyoum.com"/> The demonstrators reportedly found some documenta CDs, video and audiotape recordings pertaining to a number of recent events in Egypt including the explosion in the Two Saints Church in Alexandria on December 31, 2010, in which the state security apparatus, under [[Habib el-Adli|Habib El-Adli]], was allegedly involved. Documents pertaining to spying, blackmailing and torture activities were also found and handed over to the state prosecutor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ahram.org.eg/463/2011/03/06/38/65967.aspx |title=Fires within the state security headquarters ''(burning of documents and papers)''! Simultaneous attacks on the the headquarters is terrifying |publisher=Ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-03-23}}</ref>
On March 6, 2011 It was reported that among the documents that were found in a readable condition in the Egyptian State Security buildings was a file from the office of Hassan Abdulrahman, the former deputy interior minster under Mubarak, with instructions to various branches of Egyptian State Security buildings to shred archived documents. These documents are believed to contain relevant information to the widespread allegations of human rights abuses by the Egyptian State Security.<ref>http://www.alwafd.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=21420:ÙÙÙ-ÙØ¤Ø§ÙØ±Ø©-Ø£ÙÙ-Ø§ÙØ¯ÙÙØ©&catid=144:ÙÙÙØ§Øª%20ÙØ­ÙÙØ©&Itemid=337</ref> In an interview with [[BBC]] Arabic TV on March 7, 2011, General F Allam, previous deputy director of the Egyptian State Security stated that the burning of these documents will not impact the evidence required for any court case, as copies of all these documents are automatically archived in confidential locations. General Allam argued that indeed an order might have been issued to shred or burn these documents due to fears that these documents may fall "in the wrong hands" if state security buildings are stormed by demonstrators.<ref>BBC Arabic: Interview with Sakina Fouad, General F Allam, and Mr Wael, a representative of the demonstrators, March 7, 2011</ref>
